description.narrative:
SIHA’s project "Negotiating Change" seeks the advancement of an alternative, moderate understanding of the Islam - one in which women’s rights can be upheld and supported. SIHA aims to counter fundamentalism and the subjugation of women within the religion and create a platform for meaningful and sustained reform in which Islam and human rights, in particular women’s rights, can co-exist. SIHA seeks to empower women activists, rights defenders and women leaders with confidence, skills and knowledge to enable them to better advocate for an alternative discourse of women and Islam.
The direct beneficiaries of the project will be civil society activists, particularly women human rights defenders, youth, university and colleges students and grassroots association members in Sudan.Other groups to be targeted by the project are moderate and progressive religious leaders and progressive leaders of the Sufi sects, teachers and worker’s association leaders, parliamentarians and policy makers.
The following major activities will be carried outas part of SIHA’s ‘Negotiating Change’ Initiative in 2015: - The production and dissemination of SIHA Journal "Women in Islam" Thisjournal contains book reviews, discussions on articles, debates, reflections of scholars, selected essays and interviews discussingwomen’s rights in Islam, the veil, marriage and divorce adultery, women’s political participation. - Training of women activists onmoderate interpretation of women’s position in Islam. This component focuses on building the capacity and knowledge of women activists, rights defenders and leaders, from Sudan, to enable them to speak out about progressive interpretations of Islam, to counter fundamentalism from within the religion itself and build a public voice of women leaders demanding for an alternative understanding ofIslam that recognizes equality and justice in the context of changing times and circumstances.

participating-org.narrative:
The Strategic Initiative is a coalition of civil society organizations operating in the Horn of Africa. ,SIHA, which means 'outcry'in Arabic, is a pioneering effort to develop and mobilise the region's women's organisations, long excluded from public and community influence and leadership. The network aims to obtain their full participation in development and peace building at the local, national and regional levels, in civil society and in government. SIHA has held a series of regional conferences in the Horn of Africa,beginning in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia in August 1995. Succeeding conferences were held in Eritrea, Djibouti, and Somaliland. The Network's objective is to work for: peace and human rights; the political empowerment of women (enhancement of women's political participation and decision-making); the recognition and support of women's economic role in the context of war-torn societies, ending of VAW.
SIHA’s regional office located in Kampala, Uganda is responsible for overseeing all SIHA Network projects and activities. SIHA has been operating in Sudan since 2002 with a very strong presence. The Sudan country team implements a range of projects in North and South Darfur, Gazira state, and in Gadarif state in eastern Sudan, as well as in Khartoum itself.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
